entities.description: A characteristic feature of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, manifesting verbally (e.g., verbal rages) and/or behaviorally (e.g., physical aggression toward people or property).
Outbursts that occur frequently (i.e., on average, three or more times per week) over at least 1 year in at least two settings.
A condition characterized by chronic severe, persistent irritability and severe temper outbursts.
A condition characterized by severe irritability, frequent temper outbursts, and severe impairment in at least one setting.
A core feature of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder, consisting of chronic, persistently irritable or angry mood that is present between the severe temper outbursts.
A condition characterized by episodic presentations of bipolar symptoms, which are not characteristic of disruptive mood dysregulation disorder.
A manifestation of disrupted mood dysregulation disorder, consisting of frequent temper outbursts, and chronic, persistently irritable or angry mood.
A condition which may be comorbid with disruptive mood dysregulation disorder but requires careful assessment due to complex histories of patients.
A condition that presents with chronic, persistent irritability, which may be characteristic of bipolar disorder in children.
A prelude to temper outbursts, occurring in response to frustration and generally exhibiting in several different settings.
A condition associated with discontinuous episodes having symptom clusters that would meet the full symptom criteria, except duration, for mania.
A condition associated with discontinuous episodes having symptom clusters that would meet the full symptom criteria for hypomania.
A condition commonly occurring in conjunction with disrupted mood dysregulation disorder and features of possible inattention.
A condition that has high rates of comorbidity in disrupted mood dysregulation disorders due to severe impairment over at least 2 weeks in feeling, physical functioning or expression.
A condition that appears in children with disruptive mood dysregulation disorders, particularly features of the onset of initial events from an earlier age.
A condition that does not require the mood to be consistently irritable or angry, which are common feature of a disrupted mood dysregulation disorder.
Conditions in which patients generally exhibit irritability and potentially higher sensitivities in response to negative emotions, along with lower verbal expression.
A feeling of sadness or hopelessness that is present most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by subjective report or observation made by others.
A diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities most of the day, nearly every day, as indicated by either subjective account or observation.
A significant weight loss when not dieting or weight gain, such as a change of more than 5% of body weight in a month.
Feeling tired or having a lack of energy nearly every day.

entities.entity: Feelings of worthlessness or excessive guilt
entities.description: Feeling worthless or excessively guilty, which may be delusional, nearly every day.

entities.entity: Diminished ability to think or concentrate
entities.description: Difficulty thinking, concentrating, or making decisions, which may be observed by others or reported by the individual.
Recurrent thoughts of death or suicidal ideation, or a specific suicide plan, which may range from passive wishes to transient but recurrent thoughts of dying.

A period lasting at least 2 weeks during which there is either depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure in all or nearly all activities, accompanied by clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

A period lasting at least 1 week during which there is a persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, combined with at least three other symptoms such as inflated self-esteem, decreased need for sleep, or increased talkativeness.

A period lasting at least 4 consecutive days during which there is a persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, combined with at least three other symptoms such as inflated self-esteem, decreased need for sleep, or increased talkativeness.
A condition characterized by feelings of sadness, hopelessness, or loss of interest in activities that occur within a few weeks after a stressor, which is not considered a major depressive episode.
The experience of losing a loved one to death, which triggers a grief response that may involve sadness, difficulty sleeping, or poor concentration.
Factors that contribute to the development of major depressive disorder, such as genetic variants, neurotrophic factors, or pro-inflammatory cytokines.
A personality trait characterized by high levels of sensitivity to stress, anxiety, or emotional instability, which increases the risk of developing major depressive disorder.
Multiple and diverse types of traumatic experiences in childhood that increase the risk of developing major depressive disorder.

entities.entity: Low income or limited formal education
entities.description: Socioeconomic factors that increase the risk of developing major depressive disorder, possibly due to stress, lack of access to quality mental health care, or marginalization.
An event or situation that causes significant emotional or psychological distress, which may trigger a major depressive episode.
A condition characterized by depressed mood that occurs only in the context of withdrawal from cocaine.
A type of psychotherapy that focuses on changing negative thought patterns and behaviors to improve mental health, although it is not mentioned in the given text.

A symptom characterized by agitation (e.g., pacing, hand-wringing) or retardation (e.g., slowed speech, thinking, and body movements) that must be observable by others and not represent merely subjective feelings.
A mood that occurs for most of the day, for more days than not, for at least 2 years (or 1 year for children and adolescents), is the essential feature of persistent depressive disorder.
One of the two (or more) symptoms present while depressed, along with other Criterion B symptoms, in individuals with persistent depressive disorder.
Psychiatric comorbidities in general, that individuals with persistent depressive disorder are at higher risk for.

A mental health condition characterized by symptoms such as markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities; psychomotor agitation or retardation; recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, suicide attempt or plan.
A mental health condition characterized by a depressed mood that occurs for most of the day, for more days than not, and two (or more) of the six Criterion B symptoms.

A mental health condition characterized by symptoms such as markedly diminished interest or pleasure in activities; psychomotor agitation or retardation; recurrent thoughts of death, suicidal ideation, suicide attempt or plan, and diagnosed for 2 years or more.
A mental health condition characterized by a mood disorder with manic episodes (with or without hypomanic episodes).
A mental health condition characterized by a depressed mood for more days than not, for at least 2 years, and two (or more) of the six Criterion B symptoms.

A mental health condition characterized by an enduring pattern of inner experience and behavior that deviates markedly from the expectations of the individual’s culture, with onset by adolescence or early adulthood, and a particularly robust risk factor for persistent depressive disorder.
Factors that may increase the risk for persistent depressive disorder.
A risk factor for persistent depressive disorder.
A time of onset for persistent depressive disorder that is associated with a higher likelihood of comorbid personality disorders and substance use disorders.
Type of intervention used for treating persistent depressive disorder.
Possible treatments for persistent depressive disorder.
One of the elevated risks of persistent depressive disorder.
An intervention that can help in managing persistent depressive disorder.
Areas that the persistent depressive disorder is likely to impact widely.
Feeling mood swings; feeling suddenly sad or tearful, or increased sensitivity to rejection (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Marked irritability or anger or increased interpersonal conflicts (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Feeling hopeless, or self-deprecating thoughts (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Anxiety, tension, and/or feelings of being keyed up or on edge (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Decreased interest in usual activities (e.g., work, school, friends, hobbies) (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Difficulty in concentrating (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Lethargy, easy fatigability, or marked lack of energy (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Breast tenderness or swelling, joint or muscle pain, a sensation of “bloating,” or weight gain (symptoms accompanying premenstrual phase during menstrual cycle).
Symptoms that occur repeatedly during the premenstrual phase of the cycle and remit around the onset of menses or shortly thereafter (symptoms accompanying premenstrual dysphoric disorder).
Clinically significant distress or interference with work, school, usual social activities, or relationships with others (symptoms of premenstrual dysphoric disorder).
Associated factors including stress, history of interpersonal trauma, seasonal changes, and sociocultural aspects of female sexual behavior (risk factors for premenstrual dysphoric disorder).
Sociocultural aspects of female sexual behavior (environmental risk factors for premenstrual dysphoric disorder).
Estimates of heritability of premenstrual dysphoric symptoms ranging between 30% and 80% (risk factors for premenstrual dysphoric disorder).

entities.entity: Daily Rating of Severity of Problems
entities.description: Scale for premenstrual dysphoric disorder symptoms (Psychometric Scores or assessment scale).

entities.entity: Visual Analogue Scales for Premenstrual Mood Symptoms
entities.description: Scale for premenstrual mood symptoms (Psychometric Scores or assessment scale).
Self-report and observer version scale for premenstrual dysphoric disorder (Psychometric Scores or assessment scale).
Conditions that may worsen premenstrual symptoms (Examples: thyroid deficiency, anemia).
Co-occurring mental disorders, medical conditions, or substance use disorders (Examples: bipolar disorder, migraines, asthma, allergies, seizure disorders).
Phases of the menstrual cycle (includes the premenstrual phase, during which symptoms occur).
Medications including hormonal contraceptives which can contribute to symptoms.
Limited social support, and cultural variations in attitudes toward menstruation, which may exacerbate symptoms.

A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.
A condition where depressive symptoms are caused by the direct physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication, or a toxin exposure).
A category of drugs of abuse that can cause a substance/medication-induced depressive disorder, e.g., intoxication with alcohol, benzodiazepines and other sedative, hypnotic, or anxiolytic drugs.
A category of drugs of abuse that can cause a substance/medication-induced depressive disorder, e.g., withdrawal from amphetamine-type substances and cocaine.
A medication that can cause substance/medication-induced depressive syndromes.
A medication that can potentially cause substance/medication-induced depressive disorder, especially if taken in high doses or in combination with other substances.
Tests used to identify the levels of a substance in the blood or urine, which can be of limited value in identifying substance-induced depressive disorder.

entities.entity: Clinical history and mental status examination
entities.description: A detailed evaluation of a patient's medical and psychiatric history, which provides the most important data in diagnosing substance-induced depressive disorder.
Factors such as poverty, racism, and marginalization that can worsen the course of substance-induced depressive disorder.
A system of codes used to record the diagnosis and billing information for substance/medication-induced depressive disorder.
A manual that provides criteria for diagnosing mental disorders, including substance/medication-induced depressive disorder.
A condition where an individual uses substances in a way that is harmful to themselves or others, which can contribute to substance-induced depressive disorder.
A personality disorder that increases the risk of developing substance-induced depressive disorder.
A mood disorder that increases the risk of developing substance-induced depressive disorder.
A mood disorder characterized by symptoms such as depressed mood, anhedonia, and changes in appetite or sleep.
Medications used to treat depression, which can also cause substance/medication-induced depressive disorder if taken in high doses or in combination with other substances.
A state of altered mental status caused by the use of a substance, which can be a risk factor for substance-induced depressive disorder.
A state of physical and emotional discomfort caused by the cessation of substance use, which can be a risk factor for substance-induced depressive disorder.

entities.entity: Family history of substance use disorders
entities.description: A risk factor for substance-induced depressive disorder.
A risk factor for substance-induced depressive disorder.

Changes in brain chemistry that can contribute to depressive symptoms during withdrawal and substance use, and influence ongoing substance use and reduce the likelihood of remission of substance use disorders.
A medication that can cause substance/medication-induced depressive syndromes.
A medication that can cause substance/medication-induced depressive syndromes.
A medication that can cause substance/medication-induced depressive syndromes.
An antiviral agent that can cause substance/medication-induced depressive syndromes.

A prominent and persistent disturbance in mood that predominates in the clinical picture and is characterized by depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities.

A prominent and persistent period of depressed mood or markedly diminished interest or pleasure in all, or almost all, activities that predominates in the clinical picture and that is thought to be due to the physiological effects of another medical condition.
A symptom of demoralization, accompanied by depressive symptoms such as low mood.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A medical condition associated with depression.
A consideration in determining whether the relationship between the mood disturbance and another medical condition is etiological.
A consideration in determining whether the relationship between the mood disturbance and another medical condition is etiological.

entities.entity: Atypical age at onset or course
entities.description: A feature of depression that can be atypical of independent depressive disorders.
A feature of depression that can be atypical of independent depressive disorders.

entities.entity: Steroids levels in blood or urine
entities.description: A diagnostic marker for Cushing`s disease, which can be associated with manic or depressive syndromes.
A medication associated with mood symptoms.

entities.entity: Full criteria for a major depressive episode
entities.description: The criteria for a major depressive episode as established by a clinician.

The PHQ-9 screening tool for the symptoms and characteristics of depression (mainly a score based tool like PHQ 9 are mental disorder screening tools [assessing signs of a condition and guiding interventions]).
1st possible causes for depression, of which may come out neurological recovery or post acute phase of depressive symptoms.
Possible risk factor for depression, especially through neuro endocrine conditions in broader spectrum
Possible risk factor for depression.
